//notes: Ultradot Pan AV is the source from which multiple companies, including NcSTAR, had copied their no-name sight
personal accounts of comparison say that the original is bad and the copycats are even worse when it comes to red-dot performance
we use the original's dimensions, except for the weight: the lengths are all the same between the different copies, and the weight is manufacturer-dependent
description: A red dot sight largely made popular by video games.  Below-average sighting performance, and abysmal battery life by modern standards.  Installs directly onto the sight rail.

variants.description: A red dot sight largely made popular by video games.  Below-average sighting performance, with reports of it holding zero very poorly.  One questionable benefit of it is a variety of emitters, each providing its own reticle pattern.  It has been suggested that all of the emitters running at the same time, even when inactive, contributes to the sight's poor battery life.  Installs directly onto Picatinny rail with an embedded mount.  <variant_black>

//weight: different sources of the same model provide different weights
we use the manufacturer-provided weight of 5.3 oz = 150.25 g
//field_of_view: assumed from a Pinty sight, which is another
no stats available for the NcSTAR model

//lifetime: the manual states battery life to be between 4000 h and 200 h, depending on the chosen brightness
as with other cases, we assume the maximum value

description: A tiny red dot sight.  Usually installed on a pistol due to its small footprint.  Requires an RMR adapter to install.  With an extra adapter, could be mounted onto the military optical sight.

variants.description: A red dot sight popular for its minuscule dimensions.  Its large dot allows for quicker target acquisition, which results in the sight being somewhat less-precise.  Installation requires an adapter for the RMR footprint.  With one such adapter, the sight can be installed on top of an ACOG sight, allowing the user to have two sights at the same time.  <variant_black>

description: A compact sight with a green dot, intended for small pistols.  Smaller dot for a reticle makes the sight slightly more-accurate at longer ranges, though sacrificing speed of target acquisition.  Installation requires a 507K adapter.

variants.description: A miniature sight intended for subcompact pistols.  Its green reticle purportedly makes it easier to see and, therefore, easier to aim with.  Mounts on an adapter after the 407/507K pattern; it is more likely that you will find one of its adapters for other mounts, particularly RMR mounts, than a direct Picatinny adapter.  <variant_black>

description: A small sight, about the length of a thumb.  Its tubular nature narrows its field of view significantly, which makes reaiming difficult, but helps with accuracy on the current target.  Installation requires a T-2 adapter.

name.str: Aimpoint Micro T-2 red dot sight

variants.description: A compact, tubular red dot sight, advertised for its ruggedness and clarity.  Has lens covers that open upwards, allowing the user to protect the sight from the elements when not in use.  Its narrow field of view makes reaiming difficult, but aids accuracy over the current target.  Mounts over the Micro T-2 footprint.  <variant_black>

//weight: manual says the weight is '3 oz / 84 g', while 3 oz = 85.049 g

description: A large green dot sight in the tube form factor.  Its construction means a restricted field of view, which makes reaiming difficult, but helps with accuracy over the current target.  Installs onto a single-ring 30mm mount.

name.str: Vortex Strikefire II green dot sight

variants.description: A large, scope-like tubular sight with a green dot.  Its construction means a restricted field of view, which makes reaiming difficult, but helps with accuracy over the current target.  Requires a single 30mm ring for a mount.  <variant_black>

notes: negative trim value is to account for the adjustment and auxiliary parts that wouldn't (presumably) get covered by taking the largest diameter of the two for the cylinder volume calculations

description: A large, futuristic-looking red dot sight that is surprisingly light for its bulk.  Its wide lens allows for a large field of view.  Installs directly onto Picatinny rail, since it comes with an embedded adapter.

variants.description: A boxy red dot sight on a riser.  Its rectangular lens provides an unparallelled field of view for its size.  Installs directly onto Picatinny rail, since it comes with an embedded adapter.  <variant_black>

//notes: cannot have a magnifier because the reticle is so far down the optic
description: An old design of a sight that'd been obsoleted far before the Cataclysm.  Its large form factor and the size and the color of its amber dot make it stand out among newer models.  Primarily known for being part of an early set of modular attachments U.S. troops used on their rifles.

variants.description: A legacy design of a red dot sight, this model is known for being part of SOPMOD: a kit of rifle attachments supplied to the U.S. Army troops.  The dot is large, at 6.5 MOA, and is colored amber.  While it's been discontinued for several years, it's still sought after by collectors and fans of recent U.S. military history.  <variant_black>

description: A modern, though still outdated, design of a red dot sight.  Its tubular design makes it easier to aim over a single target, though reaiming is hampered.  This sight was used by the U.S. Army over a decade earlier, and later superseded by a new model of a similar design.

variants.description: A modern, though still outdated, design of a red dot sight, known for being part of SOPMOD: a kit of rifle attachments supplied to the U.S. Army troops.  CompM2 is a significant improvement over the previous Trijicon RX01 sight, having a tube design, which makes it easier to stay on target while aiming.  Later superseded by CompM4, which mostly provides comfort-of-use upgrades over its predecessor.   <variant_black>

notes: neutral trim value is meant to cover attached lens covers and such

name.str: older army backup red dot sight

description: A compact, lightweight red dot sight.  This model used to be mounted on the army short-range scope, before a similar model succeeded it as the army's choice.  Despite being an older design, it still boasts comparable performance.  Its large dot makes it easier to aim, though harder to be accurate.

name.str: Noblex Sight II Plus red dot sight

variants.description: A compact, lightweight red dot sight.  This is a newer model of the sight that used to be a part of SOPMOD: a kit of rifle attachments supplied to the U.S. Army troops.  The sight of this form factor was mounted atop the ACOG as a backup for shorter-range engagements, and later superseded by the RMR.  Noblex, previously known as Docter, was still in business of producing firearm sights before Cataclysm came about.  <variant_black>

A compact, lightweight red dot sight.  This, by some miracle, is an actual Docter MRD: the very same that used to be issued to US soldiers as part of SOPMOD.  The sight was mounted atop the ACOG as a backup for shorter-range engagements, and later superseded by the RMR.  Despite having nearly-identical dimensions to its younger sibling, this one still clearly says "Docter" -- the previous name of the company -- on the side.  <variant_black>
